nodes.bodyText:
AssociativeCache is non-deterministic. Entities that are used together (e.g. portalFactoryCache and statementToBindVariableTypeCache) must be stored together in the same cache. Otherwise it is possible for only one of the caches to lose its value making pair inconsistent.
To that end I guess there is no test that would saturate these caches to breaking point. We need one.
There is a problem with life cycle of this pool. See comments below in the file
utf8Decode returns decoding status. It cannot be ignored as it indicates corrupt message. Usually when uff8 cannot be decoded BadProtocolException is being thrown
name of function argument is inconsistent with every other use. This is portalFactoryCache, right?
this pool is being cleared when server stops it seems. E.g. this is heap memory leak.

setupBindVariables is called from parse(). It clears bind variable setters list and re-populates it with whatever bind variables are. The same bindVariableSetters list is also populated from bind() when portal name is specified. So it is possible that this list will have two sets of setters.
Obviously we need a unit test covering this scenario.
here, list is being added to but not cleared beforehand

bindVariableTypes should perhaps be a simple java object to begin with. I would add a simple to-do item that we want to re-use these lists.
Realistically reuse is only possible when "statement name" disappears from cache. Then we can add IntList back to some sort of pool.
we can create these IntLists lazily only when parameterCount > 0

it is possible that peek will yield null with associative cache. Remember that cache liable to loose values when saturated.
There are two options here:


we chose different data structure to hold cache information about named statements and clear this structure when named statements go away somehow. Perhaps client closes them?


less graceful, but if we can report something on the wire about not being able to find statement by given name - we should do that
this is another site where statement can be null and this situation is unhandled
this assumes that statement is found, e.g. happy days protocol scenario. We should be prepared for protocol abuse and not NPE here. Perhaps throw BadProtocolException
for performance reasons this null check should be done outside of the method call. The rationale is that method call does not happen when statement is null
what would happen to this instance if parameterCount == 0 && statementName == null ?
wrapper.clear() sets bindVariableTypes to null. This code proceeded to fill stack with nulls. This seems rushed and untested.
We perhaps should have only one, unambiguous indicator that wrapper needs bind variable types. Perhaps "null" is better
factory and insert statement are mutually exclusive, we should have else if here
we should have WeakObjectPool here. It has array dequeue underneath but does the null checking and object instantiation behind the scenes.
